title: Welcome
text: The Oldham Lab in the Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine Division and the Department of Medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School studies how cellular metabolic reprogramming in contributes to lung diseases. We are particularly interested in the pathobiology of pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary fibrosis, studying in vitro and in vivo model systems with state-of-the-art analytical techniques, including metabolomics, stable isotope tracing, extracellular flux analyses, systems biology, and network medicine. Our motivating hypothesis is that defining how cell metabolism changes in lung disease will identify opportunities for therapeutic development.

title: William Oldham
text: Will is an Assistant Professor of Medicine and Associate Physician. His research interests include pulmonary arterial hypertension, cell metabolism, adaptation to hypoxia, and network medicine. He is also the Scientific Director of the BWH Seahorse Core facility.

title: Sarah McGarrity
text: Sarah worked in the Oldham lab from February 2020 to January 2023 as a recipient of a Novo Nordisk Foundation Postdoctoral Fellowship for research abroad in the field of endocrinology and metabolism. She joined the group from the University of Iceland where she continued her work in close collaboration with colleagues from the Center for Systems Biology. She studied how the endothelial glycocalyx contributes to endothelial cell redox homeostasis through effects on glutathione peroxidase and endothelial nitric oxide synthase enzymatic activities.
